ground_truth: The Kid's Grandfather bursts into the room, kind of rumpled, but his eyes are bright. He has a wrapped package tucked under one arm as he immediately goes to The Kid and pinches his cheek. The Mother ignores it and beats a retreat, and she is gone. There's an uncomfortable silence, then The Kid does his best to smile, suddenly passionate. The two of them are together as the Grandfather sits in a chair by the bed, and the story he's reading about transforms the monochromatic look of the bedroom into the dazzling color of the English countryside. Buttercup stands holding the reins of her horse, while in the background, Westley, in the stable doorway, looks at her. Buttercup, in her late teens, doesn't care much about clothes and hates brushing her long hair, so she isn't as attractive as she might be, but she's still probably the most beautiful woman in the world. Westley is perhaps half a dozen years older than Buttercup and maybe as handsome as she is beautiful. He gazes at her as she walks away. Westley is outside chopping wood as Buttercup drops two large buckets near him. She leaves, but his eyes stay on her. She stops and turns, and he manages to look away as now her eyes stay on him. Westley enters with an armload of firewood, gets it, and hands it to her; they stand very close to each other gazing into each other's eyes. Westley and Buttercup, outside his tiny hovel in the red glow of sunset, are locked in a passionate kiss. They stand near the gate to the farm, locked in an embrace; he smiles at her, she smiles too, and throws her arms tightly around him. They kiss, and then as Westley walks away, Buttercup watches him go. Buttercup stares out the window of her room, holding on her face, perfect and perfectly sad. In the main courtyard of Florin, replete with townspeople, livestock, and a bustling marketplace, Prince Humperdinck, a man of incredible power and bearing, stands in his royal robes on a castle balcony. Three others stand behind him: an old couple with crowns, the aging King and Queen, and a dark-bearded man who seems the Prince's match in strength: Count Rugen. A giant staircase leads to the crowd, and as a figure just begins to become visible, the crowd sees the figure and collectively holds its breath. The staircase reveals the figure appearing in the archway, and she is resplendent as she descends the stairs and starts to move amongst the people. The crowd does a very strange thing: with no instruction at all, they suddenly go to their knees.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The room was burst into by The Kid's Grandfather, kind of rumpled, but with bright eyes. A wrapped package was tucked under one arm by him as The Kid was immediately approached and had his cheek pinched. It is ignored by The Mother, and a retreat is beaten by her before she is gone. An uncomfortable silence ensues, then a smile is attempted by The Kid, suddenly passionate. The two of them sit together as the Grandfather sits in a chair by the bed, and the story he reads about transforms the monochromatic look of the bedroom into the dazzling color of the English countryside. The reins of her horse are held by Buttercup, while in the background, Westley, in the stable doorway, looks at her. Clothes aren't much cared for by Buttercup, in her late teens, and her long hair is hated being brushed by her, so the level of attractiveness she might have isnâ€™t achieved, but she is still probably the most beautiful woman in the world. Buttercup is gazed at by Westley, perhaps half a dozen years older than her and maybe as handsome as she is beautiful, as she walks away. Wood is chopped by Westley outside as two large buckets are dropped near him by Buttercup. She leaves, but her is where his eyes stay. She stops and turns, eyes now staying on him as he manages to look away. An armload of firewood is entered with by Westley, gets it, and hands it to her; standing very close to each other, gazing into each other's eyes. Outside his tiny hovel in the red glow of sunset, a passionate kiss is shared by Westley and Buttercup, locked in an embrace. Near the gate to the farm, locked in an embrace, he smiles at her; she smiles too, with her arms thrown tightly around him. They kiss, and Buttercup watches as Westley walks away. Her room's window is stared out of by Buttercup, her face held perfectly and perfectly sad. In the main courtyard of Florin, replete with townspeople, livestock, and a bustling marketplace, Prince Humperdinck, a man of incredible power and bearing, stands in his royal robes on a castle balcony. Behind him stand three others: an old couple with crowns, the aging King and Queen, and a dark-bearded man, Count Rugen, who seems to match the Prince in strength. The crowd is led to by a giant staircase, and as the figure just begins to become visible, the collective breath is held by the crowd as they see the figure. The figure is revealed by the staircase appearing in the archway, and as she descends the stairs, the movement is started amongst the people. A very strange thing is done by the crowd: with no instruction at all, they suddenly go to their knees.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The Kid's Grandfather bursts into the room, looking rumpled but with bright eyes. Carrying a wrapped package, he pinches The Kid's cheek, and the Mother exits, leaving an awkward silence. The Kid smiles, and they sit together as the Grandfather's story transforms the room's monochrome into the vibrant English countryside. Buttercup stands holding her horse's reins while Westley, slightly older and equally attractive, watches her from the stable doorway. Despite her indifference to fashion, teenage Buttercup is still stunningly beautiful. Westley chops wood as Buttercup drops two buckets nearby, and although she leaves, they exchange lingering glances. Westley and Buttercup share a close moment, gazing into each other's eyes, then passionately kiss near the farm gate at sunset. As Westley walks away, Buttercup watches him with a perfectly sad expression. Meanwhile, in Florin's bustling courtyard, Prince Humperdinck, clad in royal robes, stands on a castle balcony with his regal parents and Count Rugen, his equal in strength. As a figure descends the grand staircase, the crowd holds its breath and then kneels spontaneously as she appears resplendent among them.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The Kid's Grandfather enters, looking rumpled but bright-eyed, with a package under his arm. He pinches The Kid's cheek; The Mother leaves. An awkward silence follows, then The Kid smiles. The Grandfather sits by the bed, and as he reads, the room transforms into a vibrant English countryside. Buttercup, not focused on appearance, stands with her horse; Westley, older and as handsome, watches her. Westley chops wood as Buttercup drops buckets and leaves, but they exchange glances. He brings firewood, and they stand close, eyes locked. Under a sunset, they share a passionate kiss, and Buttercup watches Westley walk away. She stares sadly from her window. In Florin's courtyard, Prince Humperdinck stands on a balcony with royalty and Count Rugen. As a figure appears on a staircase, the crowd gasps and kneels as she descends among them.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The Kid's Grandfather makes a sudden, energetic entrance into the room, appearing somewhat disheveled, yet his eyes are sparkling with life and enthusiasm. Clutched firmly under one arm is a neatly wrapped package as he beelines straight for The Kid, affectionately pinching his cheek. Meanwhile, The Mother chooses to disregard the scene, beats a hasty retreat, and is soon out of sight. An awkward silence fills the room momentarily until The Kid gathers his composure and attempts to smile, his face lighting up with sudden fervor. Now alone together, the Grandfather settles comfortably into a chair positioned beside the bed. The transformative power of the story he begins to read vividly changes the previously dull bedroom setting into the vibrant and breathtaking colors of the English countryside. In this tale, Buttercup stands with grace, holding the reins of her horse, while in the distance, Westley, peering from the stable doorway, gazes at her with admiration. Despite Buttercupâ€™s indifference to fashion and her dislike for grooming her long, flowing hair, she remains, by all accounts, probably the most beautiful woman in the world, even if she could be considered more so. Westley, older by perhaps six years, might be just as handsome as Buttercup is beautiful. His eyes follow her as she moves away. Outside, Westley is busy chopping wood when Buttercup approaches and drops two heavy buckets nearby. She departs, but his gaze remains fixated on her, and when she halts and turns to look back, he quickly averts his eyes, yet hers linger on him. Westley, stepping inside with an armful of firewood, hands it over to her; they stand intimately close, locked in each otherâ€™s gaze. In the warm, red glow of sunset outside Westleyâ€™s modest dwelling, he and Buttercup share a passionate, fervent kiss. Standing near the farm gate, they embrace tightly; he grins at her, and she beams back, wrapping her arms around him with fervor. Their lips meet once more, and as Westley begins to walk away, Buttercupâ€™s watchful eyes follow him. In her room, Buttercup gazes out the window, her face exquisite, yet touched by a profound sadness. In the lively main courtyard of Florin, brimming with townspeople, livestock, and the hustle of a marketplace, Prince Humperdinck stands on a castle balcony, exuding immense power and authority, clad in his regal attire. Positioned behind him are three figures: an elderly couple adorned with crowns, the aging King and Queen, and a man with a dark beard who seems equally formidable, Count Rugen. A grand staircase stretches before them, leading down to the eager crowd below. As a figure begins to take shape in the archway, the crowd collectively holds its breath in anticipation. The staircase reveals this figure, majestic and radiant as she makes her descent and mingles among the people. In an unexpected display, the crowd performs a remarkable act: without any directive, they all spontaneously lower themselves to their knees.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The Kid's Grandfather makes an unexpectedly lively and energetic entrance into the room, his appearance slightly disheveled, yet his eyes are alight with vitality and overflowing enthusiasm. Firmly secured under one arm is a neatly wrapped package, which he holds tightly as he strides purposefully toward The Kid, affectionately giving his cheek a playful pinch. Meanwhile, The Mother, opting to overlook and dismiss the unfolding scene, quickly makes her exit, retreating hastily until she is completely out of sight. An awkward silence momentarily envelops the room, until The Kid regains his composure and attempts to smile, his face suddenly illuminated with renewed fervor and excitement. Now, with just the two of them remaining in the room, the Grandfather settles comfortably into a chair that is conveniently positioned beside the bed. The transformative power of the story he begins to read aloud vividly alters the previously dull and drab bedroom setting into the lively and breathtakingly colorful landscapes of the English countryside. In this tale, the character of Buttercup stands gracefully and elegantly, holding onto the reins of her horse, while in the distance, Westley, peering out from the stable doorway, gazes at her with deep admiration. Despite Buttercup's lack of interest in fashion and her disdain for grooming her long, flowing hair, she remains, according to everyoneâ€™s account, possibly the most beautiful woman in the world, even more so than one might imagine. Westley, older than Buttercup by around six years, might very well be as handsome as Buttercup is beautiful. His eyes are fixed on her as she moves away. Outside, Westley is diligently occupied with chopping wood, when Buttercup approaches and drops two heavy buckets nearby. She departs, but his gaze stays intently fixed on her, and when she pauses to look back, he swiftly averts his eyes, yet hers continue to linger on him. Westley, stepping inside with a bundle of firewood in his arms, hands it over to her; they stand intimately close, caught in each other's gaze. In the warm, rosy glow of the sunset outside Westleyâ€™s humble dwelling, he and Buttercup share a passionate and fervent kiss. Standing near the farm gate, they embrace with a tight hold; he grins at her, and she, in turn, beams back, wrapping her arms around him with fervor and warmth. Their lips meet once more and, as Westley begins to walk away, Buttercupâ€™s watchful eyes follow him closely. In her private room, Buttercup gazes longingly out the window, her face exquisite yet marked by a profound sadness. In the bustling and lively main courtyard of Florin, teeming with townspeople, livestock, and the vibrant buzz of a marketplace, Prince Humperdinck stands on a castle balcony, projecting immense power and authority, resplendent in his regal attire. Positioned behind him are three figures: an elderly couple adorned with crowns, representing the aging King and Queen, and a man with a dark beard who appears equally formidable, Count Rugen. A grand staircase stretches before them, leading down to the eager and anticipating crowd below. As a figure slowly begins to materialize and take shape in the archway, the crowd collectively holds its breath in a tense anticipation. The staircase reveals this figure, majestic and radiant, as she makes her descent and mingles gracefully among the people. In a surprising and unexpected display, the crowd performs a truly remarkable act: without any directive or instruction, they all spontaneously lower themselves to their knees.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As the Kid's Grandfather bursts into the room, his appearance is somewhat disheveled, yet his eyes sparkle with brightness, exuding both energy and anticipation. Clutching a wrapped package securely under one arm, he strides purposefully toward the Kid, focusing his attention entirely on his grandchild. Without hesitation, he reaches out, playfully pinching the Kid's cheek with affection and familiarity. Meanwhile, the Mother, choosing to disengage from the scene, quietly turns away and leaves the room, retreating without a word and closing the door behind her. In the wake of her departure, a palpable, uncomfortable silence envelops the room, creating a moment of awkwardness. Breaking this silence, the Kid musters a smile, one that begins hesitantly but soon transforms into something more genuine, driven by a sudden surge of passion and eagerness. The Grandfather, sensing the change in the atmosphere, moves to sit comfortably in a chair by the bed, signaling the start of a shared experience. As he begins to read, the story's vivid imagery takes hold, magically transforming the drab monochrome of the bedroom into the splendid, vibrant colors of the English countryside. Within this imagined landscape, Buttercup stands gracefully, clutching the reins of her horse, while Westley, positioned thoughtfully in the stable doorway, gazes at her with admiration. Buttercup, in her late teens, possesses a natural beauty that shines through her simple demeanor, as she pays little attention to fashion and avoids grooming her long hair, yet remains arguably the most beautiful woman in the world. Westley, perhaps six years her senior, mirrors her beauty with handsomeness of his own. His eyes follow her intently as she walks away, captivated by her presence. Meanwhile, Westley finds himself outside engaging in the task of chopping wood with focused dedication, when Buttercup approaches, dropping two large buckets near him with a soft thud. She turns to leave, but his gaze lingers on her retreating form. Sensing this, she stops and turns back towards him, catching him in the act of looking away, yet now it's her eyes that remain fixed on him. Westley then moves to enter the house, carrying an armload of firewood, which he offers to her as he approaches. As she accepts the bundle, they find themselves standing in close proximity, their eyes locking and holding an intense gaze. The passage of time brings them outside Westley's modest hovel at sunset, where the red glow paints the scene of their passionate kiss. They stand together at the farm gate, ensconced in an embrace filled with warmth and mutual affection; he smiles gently at her, prompting her to respond with her own radiant smile before she throws her arms tightly around him. They kiss once more, savoring the moment, before Westley resumes his path, walking away as Buttercup stays behind, her eyes trailing after him, filled with longing. Alone in her room, Buttercup gazes out the window, her face a picture of perfection tinged with profound sadness. Meanwhile, in the main courtyard of Florin, bustling with townspeople and livestock amidst a lively marketplace, Prince Humperdinck, a man of commanding presence and regal authority, stands elevated on a castle balcony, adorned in his royal robes. Behind him stand three other figures: an elderly couple wearing crownsâ€”the King and Queen in their twilight yearsâ€”and a dark-bearded man, Count Rugen, whose strength seems to match that of the Prince. A grand staircase descends to the crowd below, and as a new figure begins to materialize at the top, the assembled onlookers collectively hold their breath in anticipation. As the staircase gradually unveils her, she emerges in the archway, descending the stairs with poise and grace, her appearance resplendent. As she moves amongst the people, an unexpected and extraordinary thing happens: with no guidance or directive, the crowd, as one, reverently lowers themselves to their knees, awed by her presence.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The Kid's Grandfather enters the room, looking a bit disheveled but with bright eyes, carrying a wrapped package. He immediately approaches The Kid and affectionately pinches his cheek, while the Mother quietly exits the scene. After an awkward pause, The Kid smiles passionately, and the Grandfather sits by the bed, reading a story that transforms the drab bedroom into the vibrant English countryside. In the story, Buttercup holds her horseâ€™s reins with Westley gazing at her from the stable doorway. Despite Buttercup's indifference to her appearance, she is still remarkably beautiful, and Westley, slightly older, matches her beauty with his handsomeness. As Buttercup walks away, Westley watches her, and she turns back to find him looking. Later, she approaches Westley, who is chopping wood, and leaves two buckets for him, catching his gaze as she departs. He brings an armload of firewood inside and hands it to her, and they stand close, gazing into each other's eyes. Outside Westleyâ€™s hut at sunset, they share a passionate kiss, embracing near the farm gate with smiles and another kiss before Westley departs, leaving Buttercup watching. Buttercup, perfectly sad, gazes out her room window. In Florin's bustling main courtyard, Prince Humperdinck stands on a castle balcony with an elderly King and Queen and Count Rugen, a man of equal strength, behind him. As a figure appears at the top of a grand staircase, the crowd collectively holds its breath. The figure descends the staircase, moving gracefully amongst the townspeople, who, without prompting, spontaneously kneel.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The Kid's Grandfather bursts into the room, kind of rumpled, but his eyes are bright with excitement, reminiscent of a child eager to share a secret. He has a wrapped package tucked under one arm as he immediately goes to The Kid, who is lying in bed recovering from a mild illness, and pinches his cheek. The Mother, preoccupied with household duties, ignores it and beats a retreat, and she is gone. There's an uncomfortable silence, then The Kid does his best to smile, suddenly passionate, realizing his Grandfather's visits always bring stories from distant lands and times. The two of them are together as the Grandfather sits in a chair by the bed, and the story he's reading about transforms the monochromatic look of the bedroom into the dazzling color of the English countryside, known for its rolling hills and quaint villages. Buttercup stands holding the reins of her horse, a magnificent creature of noble breeding, while in the background, Westley, in the stable doorway, looks at her. Buttercup, in her late teens, doesn't care much about clothes and hates brushing her long hair, so she isn't as attractive as she might be, but she's still probably the most beautiful woman in the world, admired by all who see her. Westley is perhaps half a dozen years older than Buttercup and maybe as handsome as she is beautiful, with a rugged charm that matches his earnest nature. He gazes at her as she walks away. Westley is outside chopping wood as Buttercup drops two large buckets near him, a common task in their simple village life. She leaves, but his eyes stay on her. She stops and turns, and he manages to look away as now her eyes stay on him. Westley enters with an armload of firewood, gets it, and hands it to her; they stand very close to each other gazing into each other's eyes, a silent exchange of unspoken affection. Westley and Buttercup, outside his tiny hovel in the red glow of sunset, which colors the sky in warm hues, are locked in a passionate kiss. They stand near the gate to the farm, locked in an embrace; he smiles at her, a smile that promises tomorrow, she smiles too, and throws her arms tightly around him. They kiss, and then as Westley walks away, Buttercup watches him go, already counting the moments until his return. Buttercup stares out the window of her room, holding on her face, perfect and perfectly sad, reflecting a longing for days gone by. In the main courtyard of Florin, replete with townspeople from every corner of the kingdom, livestock, and a bustling marketplace offering exotic wares, Prince Humperdinck, a man of incredible power and bearing, known for his strategic mind and ambition, stands in his royal robes on a castle balcony. Three others stand behind him: an old couple with crowns, the aging King and Queen, who have ruled justly for decades, and a dark-bearded man who seems the Prince's match in strength: Count Rugen, notorious for his ruthless efficiency. A giant staircase leads to the crowd, and as a figure just begins to become visible, the crowd sees the figure and collectively holds its breath in anticipation. The staircase reveals the figure appearing in the archway, and she is resplendent as she descends the stairs and starts to move amongst the people, a vision of grace and dignity. The crowd does a very strange thing: with no instruction at all, they suddenly go to their knees, a spontaneous act of reverence for their beloved future queen.

Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. they stand very close to each other gazing into each other's eyes. Westley and Buttercup outside. his tiny hovel in the red glow of sunset are locked in a passionate kiss. They stand near the gate to the farm locked in an embrace. he smiles at her. she smiles too and throws her arms tightly around him. They kiss and then as Westley walks away Buttercup watches him go. Buttercup stares out the window of her room holding on her face perfect and perfectly sad. In the main courtyard of Florin replete with townspeople livestock and a bustling marketplace. Prince Humperdinck a man of incredible power and bearing stands in his royal robes on a castle balcony. Three others stand behind him an old couple with crowns the aging King and Queen and a darkbearded man who seems the Prince's match in strength. Count Rugen. A giant staircase leads to the crowd and as a figure just begins to become visible the crowd sees the figure and collectively holds its breath. The staircase reveals the figure appearing in the archway and she is resplendent as she descends the stairs and starts to move amongst the people. The crowd does a very strange thing with no instruction at all they suddenly go to their knees.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: The Kid's Grandfather bursts into the room kind of rumpled but his eyes are bright. He has a wrapped package tucked under one arm as he immediately goes to The Kid and pinches his cheek. The Mother ignores it and beats a retreat and she is gone. There is an uncomfortable silence then. The Kid does his best to smile suddenly passionate. The two of them are together as the Grandfather sits in a chair by the bed and the story he is reading about transforms the monochromatic look of the bedroom into the dazzling color of the English countryside. Buttercup stands holding the reins of her horse while in the background. Westley in the stable doorway looks at her. In the main courtyard of Florin replete with townspeople livestock and a bustling marketplace. Prince Humperdinck a man of incredible power and bearing stands in his royal robes on a castle balcony. Three others stand behind him an old couple with crowns the aging King and Queen and a darkbearded man who seems the Prince's match in strength. Count Rugen. A giant staircase leads to the crowd and as a figure just begins to become visible the crowd sees the figure and collectively holds its breath. The staircase reveals the figure appearing in the archway and she is resplendent as she descends the stairs and starts to move amongst the people. The crowd does a very strange thing with no instruction at all they suddenly go to their knees.

He has a wrapped package tucked under one arm as he immediately goes to The Kid and pinches his cheek. The Mother ignores it and beats a retreat and she is gone. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The Dog's Trainer storms into the barn, quite disheveled, but his hands are steady. He has a knotted rope draped over one shoulder as he quickly approaches The Dog and scratches its paw. The Chef overlooks it and sprints a departure, and she vanishes. There's an awkward buzz, then The Dog tries its best to growl, suddenly excited. The pair of them are together as the Trainer lounges on a stool by the crate, and the tale he's narrating about changes the dull hue of the yard into the vibrant colors of the Italian meadow. Daisy stands clutching the leash of her cat, while in the backdrop, Charlie, in the barn entrance, stares at her. Daisy, in her late twenties, doesn't care much about shoes and avoids grooming her curly fur, so she isn't as charming as she might be, but she's still likely the smartest creature in the town. Charlie is possibly a handful of years older than Daisy and maybe as clever as she is intelligent. He watches her as she runs away. Charlie is indoors brewing tea as Daisy drops two heavy bags next to him. She exits, but his gaze lingers on her. She pauses and pivots, and he manages to turn away as now her gaze lingers on him. Charlie enters with an armful of newspapers, grabs it, and offers it to her; they stand very near to each other peering into each other's eyes. Charlie and Daisy, outside his quaint shack in the golden light of dawn, are engaged in a gentle hug. They stand beside the path to the orchard, locked in a cuddle; he grins at her, she grins too, and wraps her legs snugly around him. They hug, and then as Charlie trudges away, Daisy follows him with her eyes. Daisy gazes out the portal of her cabin, focusing on her expression, serene and subtly wistful. In the grand courtyard of Rivendell, filled with villagers, birds, and a thriving bazaar, Duke Thistledown, a person of immense stature and demeanor, stands in his noble garments on a palace deck. Three others stand behind him: an elderly pair with ornate hats, the frail Duke and Duchess, and a light-bearded woman who seems the Duke's equal in courage: Baroness Greystone. A colossal ramp leads to the throng, and as a silhouette barely starts to emerge, the crowd observes the figure and collectively holds its excitement. The ramp unveils the silhouette appearing in the portal, and she is stunning as she ascends the slope and begins to weave amongst the throng. The crowd does a very peculiar thing: without any guidance at all, they suddenly drop to their feet.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The Grandfather, disheveled but bright-eyed, enters the room with a package and greets The Kid warmly. After the Mother leaves, an awkward silence ensues, but the Grandfather captivates The Kid with a story that transforms the room into a vivid English countryside scene. Buttercup, a teenage girl indifferent to her appearance, is considered one of the world's most beautiful women. Westley, a handsome young man, admires her as she walks away. They share a passionate connection, culminating in a romantic embrace at sunset. Meanwhile, in Florin's bustling courtyard, Prince Humperdinck, the powerful ruler, appears with his entourage, including the aging King, Queen, and Count Rugen. As a figure descends from the castle, the crowd astonishingly kneels in awe.
